citation.article-title: Oceanisphaera ostreae sp. nov., isolated from seawater of an oyster farm, and emended description of the genus Oceanisphaera Romanenko et al. 2003
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Oceanisphaera ostreae sp. nov.
Oceanisphaera ostreae (os.tre′a.e. L. gen. n. ostreae of/from an oyster).
Cells are Gram-stain-negative, non-spore-forming and short rods or rods (0.5–1.0×1.2–5.0 µm).
Motile by means of a single polar flagellum (Supplementary Fig. S2).
Colonies on MA are circular to slightly irregular, slightly convex, smooth, glistening, light greyish yellow and 1.0–1.5 mm in diameter after incubation for 3 days at 25 °C.
Optimal growth occurs at 25 °C; grows at 4 and 37 °C, but not at 40 °C.
Optimal pH for growth is between 7.0 and 8.0; grows at pH 5.0, but not at pH 4.5.
Optimal growth occurs in the presence of 2 % (w/v) NaCl; grows in 0–10.0 % (w/v) NaCl.
Growth does not occur under anaerobic conditions on MA or on MA supplemented with nitrate.
Hypoxanthine, xanthine, tyrosine and Tweens 20, 40, 60 and 80 are hydrolysed, but casein and starch are not.

Acid is produced from d-ribose, but not from l-arabinose, cellobiose, d-fructose, d-galactose, d-glucose, myo-inositol, lactose, maltose, d-mannitol, d-mannose, melezitose, melibiose, raffinose, l-rhamnose, d-sorbitol, sucrose, trehalose or d-xylose.
The major fatty acids (>10 % of total fatty acids) are iso-C15 : 0 2-OH and/or C16 : 1ω7c, C18 : 1ω7c and C16 : 0.
The major polar lipids are phosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylethanolamine; diphosphatidylglycerol is present as a minor component.
Other phenotypic properties are shown in Table 1.
The type strain is T-w6T ( = KCTC 23422T = CCUG 60525T), isolated from seawater of an oyster farm in the South Sea, Korea.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 56.6 mol% (HPLC).
